dataset.title: Observed Spring Phenology Responses in Experimental Environments (OSPREE)

abstract.para: This meta-analytic database of the published literature on spring phenology (e.g., budburst or leafout) of woody species in controlled environments (e.g., growth chambers) was designed to better inform models and related forecasts of spring phenology by: (1) allowing tests of the relative effects of chilling, forcing and photoperiod (daylength) on spring phenological responses and (2) giving an overview of the design of most experimental studies to date.

intellectualRights.para: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Global with more studies in Europe and North America

description.para: We searched the literature for research papers that experimentally addressed controls of temperature, chilling, and/or photoperiod requirements on the spring phenology of woody plant species. To identify phenological experiments that manipulated chilling, forcing, and/or photoperiod, we searched both ISI Web of Science and Google Scholar with the following terms:
1. TOPIC = (budburst OR leaf-out) AND (photoperiod or daylength) AND temperature*, which yielded 85 publications
2. TOPIC = (budburst OR leaf-out) AND dorman*, which yielded 193 publications
These initial searches yielded 201 unique papers, which we reviewed and assessed for inclusion in the database.

This subset of the OSPREE database includes only studies that measured days to budburst. Many studies communicated results differently (e.g., days to budburst, degree-days to budburst, percent budburst); we standardized papers to common units whenever possible. Most studies defined budburst as initial "green tips" (33/49 papers) and the majority of studies(34/49) required only one bud to have met the defined criteria of budburst. For studies that quantified multiple measurements of percent budburst over time (days), we extracted one value of "days to budburst" of these multiple measurements to

make them comparable to other studies. To extract this summary value, we selected the days to budburst when percent budburst was closest to 90%, including estimates as low as 49.5% budburst. We further restricted studies included in the database to those for which forcing, chilling, and photoperiod treatments could be quantitatively identified. For methods used to estimate chilling, forcing, and photoperiod when they were not reported in the published manuscript and additional details, please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich. "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming." Nature Climate Change.
This database includes the subset of OSPREE studies measuring days to budburst; this includes data across 72 experiments (in 49 papers), 39 years, and 203 species.

otherEntity.entityDescription: Code, sourced in models_stan_knb.R, to prepare data for model fitting
Code sourced in models_stan_knb.R to prepare data for model fitting

Sourced code to combine rarely studied species into "complexes" when including only studies in which multiple cues are manipulated. For details please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich; "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming," 2020. Nature Climate Change.

Sourced code to combine rarely studied species into "complexes." For details please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich; "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming," 2020. Nature Climate Change.

Sourced code to combine rarely studied species into "complexes" when crops are excluded. For details please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich; "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming," 2020. Nature Climate Change.

Stan code for the main budburst model, a Bayesian hierarchical model predicting days to budburst model with including main effects of chilling, forcing, and photoperiod, with species modeled hierarchically. For details please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich; "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming," 2020. Nature Climate Change.

OSPREE budburst database, with estimated experimental and field chilling, forcing, and photoperiod. For details please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich; "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming," 2020. Nature Climate Change.

attribute.attributeDefinition: short name for each publication (see Ettinger et al 2020 for details).
Used to differentiate between separate experiments within a publication (e.g., exp1, exp2, exp3)
Genus of individual
Species of individual
Latitude of location where plant material used in experiment was collected, in decimal degrees, negative = south of 0 degrees
The date on which plant material was collected from the field, prior to being placed in experimental conditions, (dd-mm-yyyy)

Air temperature, in degrees Celsius, of chilling treatment in experimental chilling manipulations. Blank cells and cells marked "ambient" may indicate field chilling (these data contained in a separate column).
Length, in days, of chilling treatment, for experimental chilling manipulation only
Air temperature, in degrees Celsius, of forcing treatment during daylight conditions
Air temperature, in degrees Celsius, of forcing treatment during "night" conditions, if different than day conditions
"daytime" photoperiod of forcing treatment, in hours
response reported (e.g. percent budburst). If response variable is time (e.g., days to budburst), then entry is "timeonly"
days to the response (e.g. days to budburst)
Forcing temperature, in degrees Celsius, used in models. Incorporates adjustments due to ramped and ambient treatments, as well as treatments that used different temperatures in day versus night
"daytime" photoperiod of forcing treatment, in hours, used in models. Incorporates adjustments due to ramped and ambient treatments
Total chilling, calculated according to the Utah Model, including both estimated field chilling and experimentally applied chilling
days to the response (e.g. days to budburst), inputted into models
Type of forcing treatment applied

codeDefinition.definition: Experimentally applied within a controlled environment chamber, generally constant temperature
Forcing treatment consisted of ambient conditions
Experimentally applied force in which temperatures gradually change (usually increasing) across the duration of the experiment

attribute.attributeDefinition: Type of photoperiod treatment applied during the forcing treatment

codeDefinition.definition: Ambient photoperiod, not experimentally controlled or manipulated
Photoperiod controlled experimentally, usually with a constant duration (e.g., 8 hours od daylength)
Experimentally applied daylength that increase or decrease gradually throughout the experiment (e.g., daylength is 6 hours at the start of the experiment and increases gradually to 12 hours)
no information on photoperiod treatment provided in the study

attribute.attributeDefinition: Type of chilling treatment

codeDefinition.definition: Experimental chilling (i.e., controlled temperature and duration, applied in controlled environment chambers)
Field chilling, estimated from climate data (see Ettinger et al 2020 for details)
Includes both estimates of field chilling and experimental chilling bothrep Both experimental and field chilling reported in the original study
Includes both experimental and field chilling, which were reported in the original study

attribute.attributeDefinition: Total cumulative chilling, calculated according to the Chilling Hours Model, including both estimated field chilling and experimentally applied chilling
Total cumulative Chilling, in units of Chill Portions, including both estimated field chilling and experimentally applied chilling

otherEntity.entityDescription: R code for excuting stan code to fit main budburst model and all species model. For details please see Ettinger, Chamberlain, Morales-Castilla, Buonaiuto, Flynn, Savas, Samaha & Wolkovich; "Winter temperatures predominate in spring phenological responses to warming," 2020. Nature Climate Change.
sourced code required for running models_stan_knb.R
